title: 107_s156
content:
The "After School Education and Anti-Crime Act of 2001" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students, reduce juvenile crime, and prevent youth from becoming victims of crime by providing productive activities during after school hours. Congress finds that today's youth face increased social risks, spend more unsupervised time alone, and are most at risk of violence between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. Academic failure consequences are dire, and after school programs help address social issues. Governors and law enforcement officials support expanding after school programs. The Fraternal Order of Police and the International Union of Police Associations, representing 360,000 police officers, urge public officials to provide after school programs with recreation, academic support, and community service for school-age children and teens in the United States. They emphasize the importance of safe and positive learning environments during after school hours. The Act aims to increase academic success, promote safe after-school environments, provide alternatives to negative activities, and reduce juvenile crime. It also amends the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act to increase program authorization. The Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to require recipients to provide a certain percentage of the annual cost of activities from sources other than federal funds. The Century Community Learning Centers Act now requires recipients to maintain their fiscal effort from non-Federal sources for activities funded under the project each year. SEC. 7. USES OF FUNDS. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to allow grants for establishing or expanding community learning centers that offer various activities, including job skills preparation. After school programs must include mentoring, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training, with the option to include drug prevention, health counseling, and job skills preparation. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to allocate a minimum of two-thirds of funds for after school programs, which may include job skills preparation activities. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATION.

Amendment to Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act includes provisions for local educational agencies, schools, or consortia to involve volunteers from various communities, engage youth in designing after school activities, conduct outreach creatively, request donations of equipment, and collaborate with park and recreation agencies to avoid duplication of activities.

SEC. 9. COMMUNITY LEARNING CENTER DEFINED. SEC. 9. COMMUNITY LEARNING CENTER DEFINED. Section 10906 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include law enforcement organizations such as the Police Athletic and Activity League. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 10907 is amended to increase funding for fiscal years 2002-2006 to carry out this part. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect on October 1, 2001.
